Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Intrinsic, Universal Fouling Resistance in Membranes for More Sustainable Production, Use, and Recovery of Critical Resources

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1550316
Arias Chavez

Membrane fouling limits achieving energy efficiency of membrane technologies for water treatment. This results in economic, environmental, and energetic penalties on potentially new applications of membranes for resource reclamation. The PI has recently determined that polyamide morphology can vary significantly across membrane surfaces and that some regions can have a very low surface roughness. The proposed study will improve the scientific understanding of the relationship between thin-film composite membrane structure and performance.

An in-depth, localized evaluation of the low-roughness regions of these membranes is proposed to: (1) better understand and quantify the polyamide layer structure in these regions, and
(2) demonstrate that high standards for membrane permeability and selectivity are maintained in these local regions. Electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy and surface titration methods will be used to obtain additional quantitative information about the structure of the polyamide layer in low-roughness regions. New equipment for testing active layer membrane permeability and selectivity will be developed to allow membrane transport performance to be measured on the same scale (< 1 cm2) as roughness characterization work. This work, if successful, will demonstrates that low-roughness polyamide regions retain excellent permeability and selectivity, and will serve as a proof-of-concept for the development of a new line of membranes effective against foulants of all types rather than just one type of foulant. To increase outreach and diversity, the PI will partner with a local high school to involve the students in thinking about decentralized water treatment technologies. POR.DRECONTENT:
Achieving sustainability in our water and energy sectors depends, in part, on the development of energy efficient technologies for the provision of drinking water from both conventional and unconventional sources.  These unconventional sources may include seawater and wastewater, which tend to have more contaminants than traditional drinking water sources (e.g., lakes, rivers, and groundwater).  Since our demand for freshwater exceeds the supply available in these conventional resources, we inevitably turn to unconventional sources to make up the difference.  Highly selective membranes can be used to safely separate unconventional water sources so that drinking water can be obtained, but the energy cost for the separation can be high, particularly when membranes are exposed to foulants.  When these foulants build up on the surface of membranes, they reduce water flux through the membrane, forcing operators to increase energy inputs in order to maintain production rates.  Foulants can also reduce membrane selectivity and integrity in certain cases.  Preventing membrane fouling, then, is critically important for achieving water security at low energy cost.

 

The membranes used in reverse osmosis, one of most selective membrane processes, are particularly susceptible to fouling.  One reason for this is that their polyamide selective layers are very rough on a microscopic scale, with irregular, densely-packed nodules and peaks emerging from their surfaces at heights of 100 - 1000 nm.  As foulant-laden feed water sweeps over the surface of a membrane, foulants can easily become trapped in these raised features, causing membrane performance to decline.  If we could make a membrane that was just as permeable and selective as a conventional reverse osmosis membrane, but with a smooth surface instead of a rough one, we would make great progress in preventing membrane fouling and advancing our water and energy sustainability as a society.  However, the conventional understanding is that a membrane selective enough for desalinating seawater is intrinsically rough; if a membrane isn't rough, then it isn't selective. 

 

Our work closely examined the surfaces of seawater desalination membranes, both ones fabricated in our lab and those made commercially, to determine if membranes truly had to be rough to be selective.  We found that high quality membranes have highly variable surfaces, with some areas having 'typical' rough polyamide, and other areas, with lower frequency, having very smooth polyamide that might have significantly better resistance to fouling.  In order to discover this, we had to develop several new techniques for measuring polyamide layer roughness at nano-scale resolution and across much larger areas than are readily accessed via high magnification electron microscopy.  Ultimately, we combined scanning electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and several image processing software packages that are free or commonly available to develop a method that would allow us to accurately characterize the membrane surface at high resolution and across large areas.  This allowed us to inspect the membrane surface more thoroughly than had been done in the past.

 

We also determined that we could use a faster and less destructive method than scanning electron microscopy to determine membrane surface roughness: water contact angle measurement.  The angle that forms between the edge of a water droplet and the surface it sits on depends on both the affinity of water for that surface (which is based on material interactions) as opposed to air, and the micro- and nano-scale roughness of the surface, since this roughness can effectively introduce air into the interface between the water droplet and the surface that supports it.  We measured the contact angles of water drops placed on the membrane surface and then examined the area exactly under the drop, marked with a dye, with our advanced microscopy technique, to determine the structure and roughness of the membrane surface in that area.  We observed a strong correlation between contact angle and membrane surface roughness.  This will allow us to be much more time and resource-efficient in conducting future experiments on the relationship between polyamide surface roughness and other membrane characteristics as we search for a fabrication method to encourage the formation of more smooth membrane surfaces.

 

We used this knowledge to conduct a series of experiments on a specially designed reverse osmosis system that investigated whether having smoother areas would reduce membrane permeability or selectivity.  This system has miniaturized cells that match the size of the areas on membrane surfaces that have different roughnesses.  So far, our results indicate that membranes with smooth surfaces are not any less able to perform selective separations than are membranes dominated by 'typical' rough polyamide.  This promising result suggests that, with much more research, it may be possible to fabricate smooth, selective membranes that will greatly enhance the energy efficiency, robustness, and applicability of membranes in safely using many kinds of unconventional sources to meet our critical water needs.
